verses.text: Hear the word of the LORD, you Israelites, because the LORD has a charge to bring against you who live in the land: "There is no faithfulness, no love, no acknowledgment of God in the land.

rsbNotes.title: Hos 4
rsbNotes.text: 4:1–19 In this striking example of a prophetic lawsuit against Israel for violating the terms of the covenant, Hosea gives an overview of the Lord’s case against Israel and then focuses on the consequences of their rejection of the knowledge of God.

rsbNotes.title: Hos 4:1
rsbNotes.text: 4:1 faithfulness . . . knowledge. See notes 2:19, 20.

verses.text: There is only cursing, lying and murder, stealing and adultery; they break all bounds, and bloodshed follows bloodshed.

rsbNotes.title: Hos 4:2
rsbNotes.text: 4:2 swearing . . . bloodshed. These sins constituted violations of the foundational covenant document—the Decalogue (Ex. 20:2–17; Deut. 5:6–21).

verses.text: Because of this the land mourns, and all who live in it waste away; the beasts of the field and the birds of the air and the fish of the sea are dying.

rsbNotes.title: Hos 4:3
rsbNotes.text: 4:3 the land mourns. Human sin results in crises within the natural order that endanger all of life (Lev. 18:28; Is. 24:4, 5).

verses.text: "But let no man bring a charge, let no man accuse another, for your people are like those who bring charges against a priest.

rsbNotes.title: Hos 4:4–10
rsbNotes.text: 4:4–10 Attention shifts to the sins of the priests, whose failure to instruct the nation in God’s law has corrupted Israel (v. 6; Deut. 31:9–13; 33:10).

rsbNotes.title: Hos 4:4
rsbNotes.text: 4:4 let no one contend. Or, “let no man bring a charge.” According to the Mosaic law, the priests were entrusted with the task of rendering legal judgments (Deut. 17:9–13). But because of the general lack of knowledge and respect for God’s law in Israel of Hosea’s time, there was no point in bringing charges against another, because the verdicts would not be honored (the people were “like those who contend with the priest” [text note]; i.e., did not respect his decisions and teaching).

verses.text: You stumble day and night, and the prophets stumble with you. So I will destroy your mother-

rsbNotes.title: Hos 4:5
rsbNotes.text: 4:5 your mother. The nation of Israel (2:2, 5; Is. 50:1).

verses.text: my people are destroyed from lack of knowledge. "Because you have rejected knowledge, I also reject you as my priests; because you have ignored the law of your God, I also will ignore your children.

rsbNotes.title: Hos 4:6
rsbNotes.text:
4:6 My people. The nation will lose her covenant relationship with God through lack of covenant knowledge (vv. 8, 12).

knowledge. Knowledge of God is inseparable from the law of God (Introduction: Characteristics and Themes). The priests, who were responsible for teaching the law—and their descendants—were to be punished for ignoring or forgetting the law (vv. 4–10 note).

verses.text: The more the priests increased, the more they sinned against me; they exchanged their Glory for something disgraceful.

rsbNotes.title: Hos 4:7
rsbNotes.text:
4:7 I will change their glory. Or, “they will change their glory.” Ultimately, the Lord is Israel’s glory (Is. 60:19; Jer. 2:11). In Rom. 1:23, Paul condemns the sin of exchanging God’s glory for something corruptible.

shame. Idols or false gods (Deut. 32:16, 17).

verses.text: They feed on the sins of my people and relish their wickedness.

rsbNotes.title: Hos 4:8
rsbNotes.text: 4:8 They feed on the sin of my people. Taken literally, the priests, who ate portions of the animals sacrificed for sin, encouraged the people to sin. Then the priests would have more to eat (Lev. 6:26). Taken figuratively, the priests were gratified by the people’s sin.

verses.text: And it will be: Like people, like priests. I will punish both of them for their ways and repay them for their deeds.

rsbNotes.title: Hos 4:9
rsbNotes.text: 4:9 like people, like priest. No one is spared from judgment (cf. Is. 24:1–3).

verses.text: "They will eat but not have enough; they will engage in prostitution but not increase, because they have deserted the LORD to give themselves

rsbNotes.title: Hos 4:10
rsbNotes.text: 4:10 eat . . . play the whore. Food will not satisfy (v. 8), and illicit sex will not produce increase. They have left the Lord, the source of life, to practice harlotry (vv. 12, 18; 2:4; 6:10; 9:1).

verses.text: to prostitution, to old wine and new, which take away the understanding

rsbNotes.title: Hos 4:11
rsbNotes.text: 4:11 take away the understanding. Lit. “take away the [people’s] heart,” i.e., their ability to judge and think clearly (cf. Prov. 31:4, 5).

verses.text: of my people. They consult a wooden idol and are answered by a stick of wood. A spirit of prostitution leads them astray; they are unfaithful to their God.

They sacrifice on the mountaintops and burn offerings on the hills, under oak, poplar and terebinth, where the shade is pleasant. Therefore your daughters turn to prostitution and your daughters-in-law to adultery.

rsbNotes.title: Hos 4:12
rsbNotes.text:
4:12 a piece of wood. Lit. “their wood.” This may refer to the Asherah pole beside a Canaanite shrine (Deut. 16:21; Judg. 6:25–32), to some other deity (Hab. 2:18, 19), or to a sacred tree thought to give oracles (Judg. 9:37).

staff. Probably a divining rod, or perhaps a small figurine of Asherah.

spirit of whoredom. Their spiritual adultery is caused by an intoxicating and seductive power that draws them continuously into sin (“spirit of confusion,’’ Is. 19:14; “spirit of deep sleep,” Is. 29:10).

verses.text: "I will not punish your daughters when they turn to prostitution, nor your daughters-in-law when they commit adultery, because the men themselves consort with harlots and sacrifice with shrine prostitutes- a people without understanding will come to ruin!

rsbNotes.title: Hos 4:14
rsbNotes.text: 4:14 I will not punish. Not that God refused to punish the harlots and adulteresses at all (since the people as a whole will be judged), but that He would not allow them to be punished while the men who patronized them went free (cf. Gen. 38:24–26).

verses.text: "Though you commit adultery, O Israel, let not Judah become guilty. "Do not go to Gilgal; do not go up to Beth Aven. And do not swear, 'As surely as the LORD lives!'

rsbNotes.title: Hos 4:15–19
rsbNotes.text: 4:15–19 The theme of prophetic lawsuit against Israel continues as further charges of covenant disobedience are leveled (4:1–19 note).

rsbNotes.title: Hos 4:15
rsbNotes.text:
4:15 Gilgal. This important Israelite sanctuary near Jericho was situated across the Jordan from Baal-peor. From the time of the conquest, Gilgal was an important place of worship (Josh. 4:19–5:12; 1 Sam. 10:8; 11:12–15). Later in Israel’s history, Gilgal became associated with wicked and syncretistic religious practices (9:15; 12:11; Amos 4:4).

Beth-aven. This was a contemptuous nickname for Bethel (“House of God’’), the important royal sanctuary (Amos 4:4; 5:5; 7:13; 1 Kin. 12:28–33).

As the Lord lives. This orthodox oath (Judg. 8:19; Ruth 3:13; 1 Sam. 14:39) was forbidden here because they were lying (v. 2), or because it was being misused by associating the Lord with Baal worship.

verses.text: The Israelites are stubborn, like a stubborn heifer. How then can the LORD pasture them like lambs in a meadow?

rsbNotes.title: Hos 4:16
rsbNotes.text: 4:16 stubborn heifer. Israel was kicking against all of the Lord’s efforts to care for them (cf. Jer. 31:18).

verses.text: Ephraim is joined to idols; leave him alone!
Even when their drinks are gone, they continue their prostitution; their rulers dearly love shameful ways.

rsbNotes.title: Hos 4:17
rsbNotes.text:
4:17 Ephraim. Because Ephraim was by far the largest of the ten northern tribes, the northern kingdom of Israel was sometimes called Ephraim (Deut. 33:17 note).

leave him alone. The plural verb here may indicate an address to other prophets.

verses.text: A whirlwind will sweep them away, and their sacrifices will bring them shame.

rsbNotes.title: Hos 4:19
rsbNotes.text: 4:19 wind . . . wings. A wordplay on the Hebrew word meaning “wind” or “spirit” is probably intended. Not only was a destructive storm wind of divine judgment about to sweep away the people (Job 1:19), but “the spirit of whoredom” (v. 12; 5:4) was leading them to ruin.

verses.text: "Hear this, you priests! Pay attention, you Israelites! Listen, O royal house! This judgment is against you: You have been a snare at Mizpah, a net spread out on Tabor.
The rebels are deep in slaughter. I will discipline all of them.

rsbNotes.title: Hos 5:1
rsbNotes.text:
5:1 priests . . . house of Israel . . . house of the king. The fate of the northern kingdom was bound up with that of its leaders. The priests were responsible to teach the law (4:6), and the royal house was responsible for administering justice.

snare. The leaders trapped their foolish subjects.

Mizpah. Probably this is the Mizpah in Benjamin, where Samuel judged (1 Sam. 7:5, 6; 10:17–24), not Mizpah in Gilead (Gen. 31:48, 49).

Tabor. A famous mountain site located on the northeastern edge of the Jezreel Valley (Judg. 4:6). These and other northern sites had become high places of the pagan cult of Baal.

verses.text: I know all about Ephraim; Israel is not hidden from me. Ephraim, you have now turned to prostitution; Israel is corrupt.

rsbNotes.title: Hos 5:3
rsbNotes.text: 5:3 Ephraim. See note 4:17.

verses.text: "Their deeds do not permit them to return to their God. A spirit of prostitution is in their heart; they do not acknowledge the LORD.

rsbNotes.title: Hos 5:4
rsbNotes.text: 5:4 spirit of whoredom. See note 4:12. They “know not the Lord” truly (4:1, 6), nor can they return or repent (cf. Jer. 13:23).

verses.text: Israel's arrogance testifies against them; the Israelites, even Ephraim, stumble in their sin; Judah also stumbles with them.

rsbNotes.title: Hos 5:5
rsbNotes.text: 5:5 testifies. The sins of the people testify against them in the Lord’s covenant lawsuit against His people (ch. 4 note).

verses.text: When they go with their flocks and herds to seek the LORD, they will not find him; he has withdrawn himself from them.

rsbNotes.title: Hos 5:6
rsbNotes.text: 5:6 With their flocks . . . to seek. The Lord will not be found through the offering of their ritual sacrifices (4:13; 1 Sam. 15:21–23; Is. 1:11–17; Mic. 6:6–8).

verses.text: They are unfaithful to the LORD; they give birth to illegitimate children. Now their New Moon festivals will devour them and their fields.

rsbNotes.title: Hos 5:7
rsbNotes.text:
5:7 alien children. Like an unfaithful wife and mother, Israel gives birth to children that were literally and religiously illegitimate (4:6, 13, 14).

new moon. The festivals brought judgment, instead of the Lord’s blessing on their wombs and crops as they had imagined would happen (cf. Is. 1:13, 14).

verses.text: "Sound the trumpet in Gibeah, the horn in Ramah. Raise the battle cry in Beth Aven; lead on, O Benjamin.
Ephraim will be laid waste on the day of reckoning. Among the tribes of Israel I proclaim what is certain.

rsbNotes.title: Hos 5:8
rsbNotes.text:
5:8 Blow . . . Sound the alarm. These commands sound the watchman’s cry to warn of an approaching enemy (Judah) from the south (cf. 8:1). The Syro-Ephraimite war described in 2 Kin. 16:5–9 and 2 Chr. 28:5–21 seems to stand behind this warning. See Introduction: Date and Occasion.

Gibeah . . . Ramah . . . Beth-aven. These Benjaminite towns lie in a straight line running north from Jerusalem: Gibeah, three miles; Ramah, five miles; Beth-aven (Bethel), eleven miles. At various times in their history they were claimed by one or the other kingdom (1 Kin. 15:16–22).

verses.text: Judah's leaders are like those who move boundary stones. I will pour out my wrath on them like a flood of water.
Ephraim is oppressed, trampled in judgment, intent on pursuing idols.

rsbNotes.title: Hos 5:10
rsbNotes.text: 5:10 move the landmark. The boundary lines dividing the Promised Land were considered sacred to the Lord (Deut. 19:14; 27:17; Job 24:2; Prov. 22:28; 23:10). See note Num. 27:1–11.

verses.text: I am like a moth to Ephraim, like rot to the people of Judah.

rsbNotes.title: Hos 5:12
rsbNotes.text: 5:12 moth . . . dry rot. Like a moth, or possibly like an infection (some suggest that the Hebrew word translated “moth” means “pus”), God will bring inexorable and unpleasant decay upon sinful Ephraim.

verses.text: "When Ephraim saw his sickness, and Judah his sores, then Ephraim turned to Assyria, and sent to the great king for help. But he is not able to cure you, not able to heal your sores.

rsbNotes.title: Hos 5:13
rsbNotes.text: 5:13 sickness . . . wound. Instead of turning to the Lord for healing their miseries inflicted by an enemy (cf. Is. 1:5–9; Jer. 30:12, 13), Israel turned to Assyria. Assyrian records speak of the tribute paid by Israel’s kings, Menahem and Hoshea (cf. 2 Kin. 15:17–20; 17:3).

verses.text: For I will be like a lion to Ephraim, like a great lion to Judah. I will tear them to pieces and go away; I will carry them off, with no one to rescue them.

rsbNotes.title: Hos 5:14
rsbNotes.text: 5:14 I will be like a lion. Even with Assyrian help, Israel is helpless prey before the powerful lion, the Lord (13:7; Amos 1:2; 3:8).

verses.text: Then I will go back to my place until they admit their guilt. And they will seek my face; in their misery they will earnestly seek me."

rsbNotes.title: Hos 5:15
rsbNotes.text: 5:15 I will return . . . my place. In His anger, God removes His saving presence from the people until they truly repent (3:5).
